alert.note: Alert for Central Black Hills; Northern Black Hills; Northern Foot Hills; Southern Black Hills; Southern Meade Co Plains; Sturgis, Piedmont Foot Hills (South Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS RapidCity (Western South Dakota and Northeastern Wyoming)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 23 at 8:20PM MDT by NWS RapidCity
info.description: ...Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of west central Meade, western Custer, Lawrence, west central Pennington, eastern Weston and southeastern Crook Counties through 845 PM MDT... At 820 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 3 miles west of Brownsville to 4 miles northwest of Moon to 9 miles northwest of Dewey. Movement was east at 30 mph. HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea to half inch hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible. Strong thunderstorms will be near... Lead, Deadwood, Central City, Brownsville, Cheyenne Crossing and Terry Peak around 825 PM MDT. Galena and Roubaix Lake around 830 PM MDT. Other locations in the path of these storms include Nemo, Deerfield, Tilford, Flag Mountain, Dalton Lake, Deerfield Reservoir, Medicine Mountain and Bear Mountain Lookout. This includes... Interstate 90 in South Dakota between Mile Markers 1 and 41. Interstate 90 in Wyoming near Mile Marker 207. MAX HAIL SIZE...0.50 IN MAX WIND GUST...50 MPH
info.instruction: Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms and may lead to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways. Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms. Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe shelter inside a building or vehicle. A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 900 PM MDT for northeastern Wyoming. A Tornado Watch also remains in effect until midnight MDT for southwestern and west central South Dakota.
